comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: From this article For their impact on the character of trade unionism, the most important state interventions were those on the railway and in agriculture. Under severe rank and file pressure, the London-based National Union of Railwaymen (NUR) sanctioned a national strike in Ireland in December 1916. As private interests would not meet the pay demand, the government stepped in to keep the war effort running smoothly, took control of Ireland's thirty two railway companies, and awarded a substantial war bonus. Over the next nine months the NUR's Irish affiliation rocketed from 5,000 to 17,000 members. It was a victory for the rank and file over the union’s London executive, as well as for the union over the railway companies. In 1917 NUR men launched the monthly journal New Way and developed the most articulate rank and file movement in Ireland during these years. The same article mentions James 'Big Jim' Larkin (and his hat and droopy moustache), but according to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Larkin he was in the USA between 1914 and 1923.

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: British Library, Colindale Newspaper Library "The New Way" Dublin 1917, Irish Railway Review The organ of railway workers and railway users in Ireland. Microfilm: Oct.1917 explore.bl.uk/primo_library/libweb/action/search.do?dscnt...

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content: Definitely unionised railwaymen, I recognise at least one of their union fobs (see my notes in pic).

comment.author: 23885771@N03
comment._content:
Wish I could get a clear image of their lapel badges and other fobs!

These men would have been National Union of Railwaymen (NUR) members. They were generally station workers whereas engineers, train drivers and their firemen were members of other railway unions.
